Graphical abstract Single atom Co with a novel Co-O2N2 coordination configuration is a multifunctional active center, which not only effectively enhances the chemisorption of LiPSs, but also significantly catalyzes the bidirectional LiPSs conversion, thereby inhibiting the shuttle effect. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries suffer from the shuttle effect of soluble lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and slow redox kinetics, significantly limiting their practical application. Although single-atom catalysts (SACs) offer a promising strategy to address these challenges, designing materials with optimal adsorption force and high catalytic activity remains a grand challenge. Here, we present a cobalt (Co)-based SAC with unique Co-O2N2 coordination structures for Li-S batteries. Both experimental and theoretical studies demonstrate that O, N-coordinated Co single atoms anchored on a porous carbon framework (Co/NOC) effectively capture LiPSs and dramatically catalyze bidirectional polysulfide conversion. The expanded carbon layer spacing facilitates lithium ions diffusion and maximizes the exposure of active sites. As a result, Li-S batteries incorporating Co/NOC as separators exhibit outstanding rate performance (906.6 mAh g−1 at 3 C) and exceptional cycling stability, even at −10 °C. Furthermore, with a high sulfur loading of 12.0 mg cm−2, the areal specific capacity reaches up to 12.36 mAh cm−2. This work provides some useful insights for the design of high-performance SACs for Li-S batteries. Keywords Asymmetrically coordinated Co-O2N2 Zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 Melamine resin Carbon nanoflakes Shuttle effect 1 Introduction Among many battery energy storage technologies, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have received much attention because of their excellent gravimetric energy density (E g, ∼2600 Wh kg−1), low manufacturing costs, and environmental friendliness [1,2]. However, in addition to the low conductivity of sulfur (S) and discharge products (Li2S/Li2S2) and the apparent volume change of S electrode during the charge and discharge processes, the shuttle effect of high-order lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) between the two electrodes and the slow solid-liquid phase transformation kinetics of S species also hinder the actual use of Li-S batteries to a large extent [3]. Even worse, under harsh operating conditions such as high S loadings, lean electrolyte usage, and low temperatures, the above defects result in lower specific capacity (C s) and S utilization of Li-S batteries, as well as poorer coulombic efficiency, rate capability, and cycle life [4–6]. In this connection, it is very necessary to add effective adsorption-catalytic media to fix the lithium polysulfides and promote the transformation dynamics between multiphase S. At present, various metal-based catalysts, such as metal (e.g., Pt, Ni, and Co) nanoparticles [7,8], metal compounds [9–12], metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [13–15], and heterojunctions (e.g., FeCoO x S y , WO3− x -W3N4, and NbP-NbC) [16–18], have been designed to achieve rapid capture-transport-conversion of LiPSs, hoping to fundamentally solve the above problems of Li-S batteries. However, the active sites of these electrocatalysts cannot be completely exposed, and the electrocatalytic activity can only be enhanced through increasing the weight percentage of the catalysts, which is bound to sacrifice the total E g of the Li-S batteries [19]. Moreover, the surface structure of most catalysts is heterogeneous and complex, which makes it easy to produce different catalytic sites (such as faces/edges/corners), resulting in the difficulties in accurately identifying the active centers [20]. Hence, it is of great significance to design high-exposure exemplary catalysts with controllable active sites, which facilitate the disclosure of the structure-performance relationships and guide the synthesis of catalytic active materials tailored for Li-S batteries. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have become a research hotspot in the field of catalysis in recent years because of their unique quantum size effect, sharply increased surface free energy, high catalytic activity, and 100% theoretical atom-utilization [21,22]. Crucially, SACs feature monatomically dispersed metal active centers anchored in the substrate, providing an ideal channel to better clarify the intrinsic link between the active centers and the catalytic mechanisms [23]. Considering the above premises, SACs have been extensively studied in the field of Li-S batteries. The active centers of the most explored SACs in Li-S batteries so far all have the same coordination atomic structure as M−N4 (M = Co, V, Cu, Fe, Mn, Ni, and Ti) [24–26]. Nevertheless, for SACs with a coordination configuration of M−N4, the d-p orbital hybridization when interacting with S is mainly based on the hybridization of metal dz 2 orbitals and sulfur pz orbitals or metal dxz / yz orbitals and sulfur px / y orbitals, while the metal dx 2 − y 2 and dxy orbitals do not participate in hybridization [27]. This leads to some limitations in the anchoring and catalytic conversion of LiPSs. Simultaneously, the metal site matching four nitrogen (N) atoms has a plane-symmetric structure, resulting in a uniform distribution of electrons, which is also difficult to achieve optimal LiPSs adsorption [28]. Hence, it is worth considering to design novel 3d-orbital electronic structures and local chemical environments of the central metal atoms by regulating the coordination N atoms number (M−N x , x = 2–6) or introducing heteroatoms (O, B, S, and P) with different electron spin densities and atomic radius to achieve enhanced polysulfide affinity and accelerated bidirectional transformation between LiPSs and Li2S2/Li2S. For example, Zhang et al. introduced a S atom to replace the N atom in Co-N4, causing electron redistribution and enhancing the d-p orbital hybridization between S species and SACs by regulating the 3d orbital energy level of Co [28]. Recently, Sun et al. also screened Co-N3B moiety with stronger LiPSs binding ability and lower reaction barrier from a series of Co-N3X (X = N, S, P, B, Se, or Te) structures [29]. For asymmetric coordination SACs, M−N2X2 (M as the center atom, X as the coordination atom) coordination structures are currently less studied than M−N3X coordination structures. Hence, the study of the function of SACs with M−N2X2 coordination structure has guiding significance for the design and fabrication of multifunctional materials to enhance the performance of Li-S batteries. It should be pointed out that in addition to the metal centers, coordination environments, and metal load content, the effect of the substrate materials on the electrochemical activity of SACs should not be underestimated. By optimizing the structure and composition of the substrate materials and naturally matching SACs, their potential can be fully realized to synergistically increase the catalytic reaction kinetics and enhance the suppression of shuttle effect. However, how to prepare these excellent materials in straightforward and economical steps and how to reveal in detail the mechanism by which they improve the electrochemical properties of Li-S batteries remain difficult challenges. In this paper, a novel kind of O, N co-coordinated Co SACs implanted in N, O-rich carbon framework (named as Co/NOC) is developed by a mild and scalable self-templating and self-reduction way and used as a multipurpose diaphragm modification material for Li-S batteries. The exact coordination configuration of Co atoms with N/O atoms (Co-O2N2) is verified via X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis. The experimental and theoretical investigation shows that the unique Co-O2N2 coordination structure can not only improve the adsorption capacity of LiPSs by enhancing the polarity, but also significantly promote the bidirectional transformation kinetics of polysulfide as a reaction site. At the same time, the integration of N, O, and Co atoms in the Co/NOC framework improves the charge transfer performance and the number of highly polar active centers, and speeds up the kinetics of the bidirectional S redox reaction. In addition, the carbon framework containing N, O, and Co atoms possesses increased carbon layer spacing and higher specific surface area, which are conducive to the diffusion of lithium ions (Li+), exposure of SACs active site, and physical confinement of LiPSs. Consequently, the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries based on Co/NOC modified separator has been greatly improved, which provides a satisfactory initial gravimetric C s (1581.7 mAh g−1, 0.1 C), distinguished rate performance (906.6 mAh g−1, 3 C), extraordinary cycling stability (74.47% retention after 500 cycles at 1 C), expected areal C s (up to 12.36 mAh cm−2), and exciting low-temperature durability (81.97% capacity retention at −10 °C). This study further confirms the enormous potential of Co-O2N2 SACs to propel the practical use of Li-S batteries with high energy storage. 2 Results and discussion Co/NOC was prepared through the route shown in Fig. 1 . Briefly, a mixture of zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) and cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) was added into the oligomer solution of melamine and formaldehyde, and thoroughly mixed evenly. Then, the melamine resin spheres (named as MF-CTAB-Co, Fig. S1a, e, and i) were synthesized by polycondensation of melamine and formaldehyde oligomers with a precisely controlled amount of glacial acetic acid that used as the catalyst for accelerating polymerization of oligomers and the etching agent for decomposing ZIF-67 (Fig. S2). At this stage, the formed melamine resin can act as a chelating agent to combine with cobalt ions released by the decomposition of ZIF-67 to prevent high-density agglomeration. Interestingly, the use of ZIF-67 as a self-sacrificing template is conducive to more uniform growth of the melamine resin spheres, as evidenced by the lower proportion of small and medium-sized spheres in Fig. S1(a, b, e, and f) than in Fig. S1(c, d, g, and h). Finally, Co SACs anchored in an N and O co-doped carbon framework (Co/NOC, Fig. 2 a and b) with unique Co-O2N2 coordination structure were formed after annealing at 800 °C. For comparison, the N and O co-doped carbon framework (denoted as NOC, Fig. S3a and b) was synthesized without the addition of ZIF-67. Meanwhile, the N and O co-doped carbon framework containing the targeted synthesized Co SACs was also prepared under otherwise identical conditions without CTAB, denoted as Co/NOC-WC (Fig. S3c and d). It can be found that since the precursors are all based on melamine resin (Fig. S2), the Co/NOC, NOC, and Co/NOC-WC prepared by carbonization are similar in morphology to the melamine resin derived carbon (named as MC, Fig. S3e and f), showing an irregular carbon framework structure with a gully surface. Notably, the cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image in Fig. 2(c) displays that the interior of the Co/NOC consists of crumpled ultra-thin carbon nanoflakes similar to the morphology of graphene (GN), which is beneficial to the intensive electron transport during the electrochemical process. Furthermore, the high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area (S BET = 180.35 m2 g−1) and abundant mesoporous structure (Fig. S4) facilitate the exposure of more electrocatalytically active surfaces and adsorption sites, offering efficient channels for electrolyte ions transport. The rich microporous structure of Co/NOC can alleviate the overflow of soluble LiPSs, and thus efficiently physically constrain LiPSs [30]. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) image (Fig. 2d) further confirms that Co/NOC contains corrugated carbon nanosheets. Clearly, no distinct Co-derived nanoparticles or clusters are observed in Co/NOC. Unlike ZIF-67 derived carbon (denoted as ZC), there are no obvious peaks corresponding to Co-related substances in the X-ray diffraction spectra (XRD, Fig. S5a) and Raman spectra (Fig. S5b) of Co/NOC, again confirming that Co atoms do not aggregate. The XRD patterns of Co/NOC-WC and MC show a wide diffraction peak centered at 2θ = 26°, which belongs to the (002) lattice plane of graphite, proving a carbonaceous turbocharged stacked structure [31]. Compared with Co/NOC-WC and MC, the significant shifts of (002) peak of Co/NOC and NOC toward smaller diffraction angle manifest their larger carbon layer spacing (∼0.4 nm), attributed to the decomposition of CTAB inserted into the melamine resin. Appropriately increased (002) interlayer distance facilitates Li+ diffusion and exposes more active sites toward accessible polysulfides, resulting in improved C s and rate performance. After the loading of Co single atoms, the I D/I G (the intensity ratio of the disorder-induced band (D-band) and the graphite band (G-band)) value of Raman spectra increases dramatically (Fig. S5b), indicating that the addition of Co single atoms can significantly change the electronic construction as well as internal disorder of melamine resin derived carbon framework, which is conducive to elevating its electronic conductivity. The high-resolution TEM image and selected area electron diffraction results (Fig. 2e) exhibit that Co/NOC is essentially amorphous, which is consistent with the results of Raman spectroscopy. To further clarify the configuration of Co/NOC at the atomic scale, a spherical aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) test was performed. The HAADF-STEM result (Fig. 2f) reveals that numerous Co single atoms characterized by bright spots (about 2–3 Å; some of them are marked with orange circles) are evenly dispersed in the Co/NOC framework, and the distance between neighboring single atoms is much less than 1 nm. The content of Co in Co/NOC is ∼2.86 wt% by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). High-loading Co single atoms can adsorb LiPSs and accelerate its catalytic transformation as active sites, thus effectively inhibiting the shuttle effect. Furthermore, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping (Fig. 2g–k) also shows that C, N, O, and Co atoms are uniformly distributed in the Co/NOC framework. The valence state of Co in Co/NOC was studied via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Fig. 3 a). The high-resolution Co 2p spectrum of Co/NOC exhibits peaks located at 779.8/795.9 and 781.7/798.3 eV with a satellite peak of 787.2/802.3 eV, regarded as Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 orbitals of Co3+ and Co2+, respectively [29]. In the fitted spectra of N 1s (Fig. 3b) and O 1s (Fig. 3c), distinct peaks associated with Co–N and Co–O bonds are observed, respectively, verifying that the Co atom is coordinated with both N and O. Further, the local chemical states and coordination structures of Co atoms in Co/NOC were determined by XAFS measurements. In Fig. 3(d), the Co K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra show that the pre-edge curve of Co/NOC lies between those of Co foil and Co3O4, and is closer to that of Co3O4, illustrating that the single atom Co in Co/NOC has a positive charge [32]. The corresponding first-order derivative spectra of XANES (Fig. 3e) can further support the above results. Fig. 3(f) presents the Co K-edge Fourier transformed (FT) extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectra of Co/NOC, Co foil, Co3O4, and CoPc. The major peaks of Co3O4 and CoPc are located at near 1.47 Å, belonging to Co–O or Co–N coordination, and move to a relatively higher energy level (1.52 Å) in the Co/NOC, indicating a change in the Co coordination environment [28]. Besides, there is no obvious signal of Co–Co bond at 2.18 Å in Co/NOC compared to the spectrum of Co foil, which adequately indicates that the Co atoms are mostly monodisperse and coordinated with oxygen (nitrogen). As shown in Fig. 3(g) and Fig. S6, the EXAFS fitting curves of Co in Co/NOC and reference samples are in good agreement with the measured experimental data. Simulated EXAFS spectra (Fig. 3g) and fitted quantitative data (Table S1) not only prove the existence of Co–O and Co–N bonds, but also verify that the average coordination of individual Co atom in Co/NOC is double O atoms and double N atoms (namely Co-O2N2 configuration, inset in Fig. 3g). It is important to note that the EXAFS data analysis mainly exhibits statistics. Because of disorder or in-plane/edge defects, a certain amount of Co-O x N y with slightly different coordination structures will inevitably appear in Co/NOC, which will not be discussed further here. To intuitively distinguish the coordination state of the Co atoms, the wavelet transform (WT, Fig. 3h–k) was carried out at the same time, because this method possesses a high recognizability in both radial range and K-space. The WT contour chart of Co/NOC (Fig. 3k) exhibits a maximum intensity of around 3.5 Å−1, close to the first shell maximum intensity of Co3O4 (5.3 Å−1, Fig. 3i) and the maximum intensity of CoPc (4.4 Å−1, Fig. 3j), most likely owing to the backscattering between Co and O/N atoms. Moreover, the maximum WT value of the Co foil is about 7.1 Å−1, corresponding to the Co–Co bonding (Fig. 3h). Nevertheless, the Co–Co information cannot be seen in Co/NOC, suggesting the atomic dispersion of cobalt. The above synchrotron radiation results manifest that the as-prepared Co/NOC has single-atom Co center and Co-O2N2 coordination structure, which may offer a new opportunity to improve the interaction with polysulfides. On the whole, Co/NOC shows considerably practical value as an ideal membrane modifier with polar heteroatom (N and O) dopants and distinctive Co-O2N2 coordination structure, which is expected to heighten the trapping ability of lithium polysulfides and help accelerate the bidirectional S redox conversion. The Co/NOC, Co/NOC-WC, NOC, and MC were coated on a marketable polypropylene (PP) separator using blade cladding technology (the mass load of the modified coating is approximately 1.1 mg cm−2), denoted as Co/NOC@PP, Co/NOC-WC@PP, NOC@PP, and MC@PP, respectively. As seen from Table S2, the PP separator modified with the samples prepared by adding CTAB is more conducive to improving the C s and current discharge capacity of Li-S batteries, which may be caused by the expanded carbon layer spacing of the conductive framework which is beneficial to the transport of the Li+ and the exposure of the active site of adsorption/catalytic conversion. Then, we mainly took the Co/NOC and NOC prepared by CTAB as the research object for detailed characterization and analysis in the follow-up work. The SEM images of the upper surface and cross-section of the Co/NOC@PP are presented in Fig. S7(a and b), where Co/NOC is uniformly deposited on the PP membrane to build a tight protective layer with a thickness of ∼40 μm, which contribute to physically blocking the soluble polysulfide shuttle through plugging the macropores in the PP membrane. Fig. S7(c and d) is the camera photos of the Co/NOC@PP separator with the diameter of 1.6 cm undergoing folding. It is commendable that Co/NOC maintains good durability and high anchoring ability in highly folded cases and is able to resist the stress caused by bending without peeling, indicating an excellent compatibility between Co/NOC and PP. The upper surface and cross-sectional SEM photos of the NOC@PP separator are also presented in Fig. S8, displaying the surface morphology and thickness similar to that of the Co/NOC@PP separator. As displayed in Fig. S9, the fortes of the Co/NOC@PP diaphragm are first reflected in the ultra-fast electrolyte wetting speed, which can be fully wetted within 1.5 s. Since this, the rapid transport of Li+ and the efficient utilization of S can also be ensured under the condition of deficit electrolyte [33,34]. Furthermore, the transport capacity of Li+ through the separators was quantitatively evaluated by measuring the ionic conductivity (σ, Fig. S10) of the electrolyte soaked separators. The σ of Co/NOC@PP (2.87 mS cm−1) and NOC@PP (2.73 mS cm−1) separators is elevated a little compared with that of commercial PP separator (1.17 mS cm−1), manifesting that the hierarchical porous melamine resin-derived carbon rich in O and N heteroatoms accelerates the transmembrane migration of Li+ in some degree, which is beneficial to optimizing the reversible redox-reaction process of lithium polysulfides [35]. Successful preparation of polar heteroatom (N and O) dopants and monoatomic Co sites within the melamine resin-derived carbon urges further exploration on the interaction with polysulfide molecules. To directly testify the interaction between the modified separators and LiPSs, a visual penetration test was carried out using a H-model penetration device with the right side immitted with 50 mmol L−1 Li2S6 solution and the left side immitted with a mixture of dimethoxyethane (DME) and dioxolame (DOL) in equal volume ratio, which was isolated by employing PP, NOC@PP, and Co/NOC@PP separators, respectively (Fig. S11). The Co/NOC@PP separator shows an effective limitation on the diffusion of LiPSs, in which the solution in the left region maintains almost transparent even after 20 h. However, a noticeable yellow color appears in the NOC@PP penetration device and the solution on the left becomes much darker in the presence of original PP diaphragm. The powerful adsorption of LiPSs illustrates that there is a good interaction force between Co/NOC and LiPSs, which provides a favourable prerequisite for the adsorption-diffusion-transformation process of LiPSs. Meanwhile, the strong chemical interaction of Co/NOC on Li2S6 was verified by XPS measurements (Fig. S12). The S 2p XPS spectrum exhibits double coupled peaks at 162.7 and 163.7 eV, related to terminal S (ST −1) and bridging S (SB 0), respectively. Three peaks were also observed at 167.9 eV (thiosulfate), 169.7 eV (polythionate), and 170.9 eV (sulfate), indicating that Co/NOC has a good anchoring effect for Li2S6. Theoretically, the atomically controllable surface chemical structure and the outstanding ion transport rate can synergistically vest Co/NOC with a distinctive ability to regulate S conversion reactions. In order to prove this, the whole reaction process of Li-S batteries was first explored using cyclic voltammetry (CV) testing technique (Fig. 4 a). All CV curves display double reduction peaks (peak I R1, I R2) resulting from the conversion of S8 to soluble lithium polysulfides and then to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S. The two closely related oxidation peaks (peak I O2 and I O1) near 2.38 and 2.46 V refer to the oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S to LiPSs and S [36]. Notably, the Li-S batteries with Co/NOC@PP (LSBs-γ) possess the largest current density and the smallest polarization voltage at the redox peaks, demonstrating a faster S conversion kinetics, which profits by the weakened S–S bonds of LiPSs and Li–S bonds of Li2S, thanks to the bonding of Co/NOC with LiPSs and Li2S. The corresponding Tafel plots fitted from the CV curves are shown in Fig. 4(b and c). The reduction and oxidation Tafel slopes of LSBs-γ are lower than those of Li-S batteries using PP and NOC@PP (LSBs-α and LSBs-β), certifying the remarkable catalytic activity of Co/NOC in solid-liquid redox conversion. Additionally, the lithium-ions diffusion coefficient (D Li+) of Li-S batteries was determined depending on the Randles-Sevcik equation [37] employing CV results obtained at different scanning rates to identify the competence of separator modified materials to promote lithium-ions migration (Fig. S13). As expected, LSBs-γ (Fig. S13f) shows the significantly predominant D Li+ at peaks I R1, I R2, I O2, and I O1 (7.61 × 10−8, 1.52 × 10−7, 2.86 × 10−7, and 2.46 × 10−7 cm2 s−1), meaning that the addition of Co single atoms to NOC and the particular coordination environment favor the Li+ diffusion and battery redox dynamics. These outcomes indicate that Co/NOC can be used as a promising catalytic material for sulfur reduction and oxidation reactions to synchronously promote the liquid-liquid transformation of lithium polysulfides, deposition of Li2S, and subsequent reverse dissolution reactions. To uncover the electrochemical catalytic effect of the modifiers on the liquid-liquid transformation of polysulfide, the symmetrical batteries using the as-prepared compounds and Li2S6 electrolyte were assembled and assessed by the CV curves of 20 mV s−1 (Fig. 4d). Without Li2S6, the electric signal response of the battery with Co/NOC can be ignored, suggesting that the polarization phenomenon is mainly caused by the redox current of LiPSs. This is further demonstrated by a slight increase in polarization when the symmetrical battery is paired with blank stainless steel mesh electrodes and Li2S6 electrolyte. Obviously, the Co/NOC battery shows larger response currents than the NOC battery at specific polarization voltages, demonstrating that the novel Co-O2N2 coordination structure supported on NOC provides an accelerating channel for the electron transport between the electrode and LiPSs, and catalyzes the interfacial redox conversion of LiPSs. The well-matched electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the symmetrical batteries also strongly validate this greatly increased charge transfer rate, as shown in Fig. S14. It can be observed that the charge transfer resistance (R ct, 11.1 Ω) of the Co/NOC battery is lower than that of the NOC battery (21.4 Ω), which suggests that the charge transport rate at the Co/NOC auxiliary electrode/polysulfide interface is much quicker than that at the NOC based interface, further demonstrating the fluent interfacial dynamics of liquid phase lithium polysulfides transformation. With the help of the as-prepared compounds, the potentiostatic nucleation/decomposition tests of Li2S were used to investigate why Co/NOC can improve the solid-liquid transformation kinetics of polysulfides. As illustrated in Fig. 4(e) and Fig. S15(a), the nucleation test of Li2S using the Co/NOC exhibits a more obvious and earlier discharge current response than that for NOC at a constant potential of 2.05 V. In addition, a more predominant Li2S nucleation C s (446.3 mAh g−1) for Co/NOC battery contrasted to NOC battery (172.5 mAh g−1) can be noted, indicating that Co/NOC enhances the LiPSs capture and Li2S precipitation kinetics, thereby promoting the liquid-solid reactions of Li-S batteries [38]. Similarly, a higher dissolution current response (187.8 mA g−1) on the Co/NOC catalyst during the dissolution of Li2S at a constant voltage of 2.35 V (Fig. 4f and Fig. S15b) confirms its catalytic effect on the denuclearization of Li2S [39]. These characterization results can verify the anterior CV test. Carefully optimized Co/NOC with rich Co-O2N2 structure can expedite the liquid-liquid transformation of polysulfides and the deposition/dissolution of Li2S quickly, so as to enhance the C s and rate performance of Li-S batteries. The electrochemical performance directly reflects the function of Co/NOC as a diaphragm modification material in Li-S batteries. The cycle performances at 0.5 C are presented in Fig. 5 (a). LSBs-γ delivers a high initial C s of 1398.1 mAh g−1 and retains 1162.0 mAh g−1 with a remarkable C s retention of 83.11% after 200 cycles. In sharp contrast, LSBs-α and LSBs-β possess discharge C s of 669.6 and 1071.3 mAh g−1 in the initial cycle, and their remaining C s is only 382.9 and 756.0 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles, respectively. The enhanced C s retention of LSBs-γ proves that the passivation and slow redox conversion dynamics of S species are greatly resolved by the novel Co-O2N2 structure in Co/NOC with good catalytic properties and strong LiPSs chemical interactions. It is worth mentioning that the catalytic performance of Co/NOC can also be analyzed from the details of the galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves of Li-S batteries. Fig. 5(b and c) exhibits the initial GCD profiles of the LSBs-α, LSBs-β, and LSBs-γ at 0.1 C. It can be seen that the first short discharge platform is concentrated at ∼2.3 V and a long platform is at the lower voltage of about 2.1 V, where the top platform corresponds to the reduction of S to the long-chain LiPSs (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), which conforms to CV curves. The top platform discharge C s of LSBs-γ is about 418.1 mAh g−1, approaching 99.79% of the theoretical C s (419.0 mAh g−1), which is 99.2 and 49.9 mAh g−1 higher than LSBs-α and LSBs-β, respectively, indicating the better utilization rate of S and the polysulfide diffusion is highly limited by the Co/NOC dense coating [40]. Moreover, there is a distinct voltage “valley” between the first discharge platform and the second discharge platform, called the Li2S “nucleation point” (Fig. 5c). The nucleation dynamics of Li2S can be determined by the voltage difference between the “nucleation point” and the tangent line of the voltage platform [41]. LSBs-α displays a large overpotential of 22.6 mV, manifesting a high interfacial energy barrier for nucleation and deposition of Li2S. Correspondingly, the Li2S nucleation behavior of LSBs-β and LSBs-γ is greatly changed, showing an obviously decreased interfacial energy barrier (LSBs-β: 16.8 mV, LSBs-γ: 9.3 mV), which is also confirmed by the above Li2S nucleation measurements. As for the next discharge platform, the LSBs-α, LSBs-β, and LSBs-γ offer 456.4, 842.0, and 1163.6 mAh g−1, respectively. The higher C s collected for LSBs-γ at the second discharge platform indicates a higher conversion rate from long-chain polysulfide to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S. So that, the Co/NOC-modified Li-S batteries show a large increase in initial discharge capacity (1581.7 mAh g−1, 0.1 C) and a smaller voltage hysteresis (ΔE γ = 178 mV), illustrating that the Co/NOC coating layer can effectively capture polysulfide and enhance the dynamics of redox processes. Furthermore, the initial potential of the charge profiles can be used to explain the oxidation of Li2S, where the smaller initial charging voltage for the LSBs-γ (1.91 V) demonstrates that more abundant Li2S is derived on the positive side compared with the LSBs-α (2.15 V) and LSBs-β (1.95 V). This phenomenon reflects that atomic Co has exceptional catalytic activity for the nucleation and deposition of Li2S. To explore the resistance of cells with different separators, the EIS measurements were carried out. As shown in Fig. S16, LSBs-γ displays the lowest charge transfer resistance (R ct, 38.3 Ω), suggesting the best conductivity and the fastest electrochemical kinetics (104.9 and 73.1 Ω for LSBs-α and LSBs-β, respectively). The Li-S batteries with multi-step charge/discharge processes involve various intermediate products, and the R ct values of different solid-liquid-solid transformation steps can accurately respond to the variations of dynamic characteristics [42]. The ex-situ EIS results of Li-S batteries are recorded in Fig. S17. It can be observed that the R ct of all batteries decreases significantly with the discharge process proceeding, which may be related to the battery activation behavior and the reduction of S species with low conductivity. During the subsequent charge process, the R ct first decreases and then rises because of the dissolution of insulating Li2S and the final rebirth of S. It is noteworthy that the R ct of LSBs-γ is always the lowest throughout the GCD cycle, which verifies the optimal electron and ionic conductivity and good solid-liquid-solid transformation dynamics with the help of Co-O2N2 structure. The rate performance of three Li-S batteries at different current rates from 0.1 to 3 C was studied (Fig. 5d). The discharge C s of LSBs-γ is 1530.1, 1250.2, 1100.5, 1005.5, and 906.6 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 C, respectively, which are significantly higher than those of LSBs-α and LSBs-β. When it returns to 0.2 C, the C s of the LSBs-γ can rise to 1410.2 mAh g−1, still higher than that of LSBs-α (630.1 mAh g−1) and LSBs-β (1030.3 mAh g−1), demonstrating the high reversibility of the batteries. The GCD curves of the three Li-S batteries under different current densities are also given (Fig. 5e and Fig. S18). LSBs-γ still maintains flat and stable charge/discharge platforms well at the high rate of 3 C, while the other two batteries, especially the LSBs-α, undergo severe C s degradation and larger polarization with the increase of rate. The excellent rate capability of LSBs-γ confirms that the Co/NOC coating boosts the kinetic conversion of Li-S batteries, which is attributed to the efficient catalytic activity of Co-O2N2 coordination configuration and the favourable Li-ion affinity of the modified diaphragm. The long-term cyclic stability at 1 and 2 C was also investigated, respectively, and the test data are recorded in Fig. 5(f and g). After 500 cycles at 1 C, the discharge C s of LSBs-γ remained at 905.6 mAh g−1, and after 1000 cycles at 2 C, the discharge C s remained at 771.1 mAh g−1, still showing superior C s and distinguished cyclic stability to LSBs-α and LSBs-β. Although the as-assembled Li-S batteries have the above differences in electrochemical characteristics, the Coulombic efficiency under different charge/discharge conditions is approaching 100%, indicating the highly reversible S chemistry. Maintaining a relatively constant anode potential in the open circuit state can ensure the long-term application of Li-S batteries [43]. Hence, the anti-self-discharge performance under open circuit conditions is the key index to evaluate the actual use capability of Li-S batteries. The open circuit voltage (OCV) of the LSBs-α (2.14 V) and LSBs-β (2.26 V) is significantly reduced in Fig. 5(h). In contrast, the employment of Co/NOC modified separator can greatly weaken the self-discharge problem and afford a more stable OCV of 2.57 V, suggesting the vital role of Co-O2N2 structure in the restriction of LiPSs. To reveal the reasons for the optimization of the adsorption properties and catalytic behaviors of Co-O2N2 coordination environments at the atomic level, the first-principle calculations were performed. Fig. 6 (a) shows the calculated adsorption energies of nitrogen-doped GN (NG), Co-N4-C, and Co/NOC for Li2S8, Li2S4, and Li2S, respectively. Notably, the Co/NOC exhibits stronger adsorption property to Li2S8, Li2S4, and Li2S than Co-N4-C and NG because of the synergistic effect of S n 2−–Co and Li+–O chemical bonds, which accords with the Lewis acid-base interaction mechanism. Differential charge density calculations and Bader charge calculations were used to clarify the advantage of introducing Co-O2N2 moiety for improving S affinity compared with Co-N4 coordination structure. As presented in Fig. 6(b), a more denser electron cloud appears on the Co–S bonds in the Li2S-Co-O2N2 model than that in the Li2S-Co-N4 model, which is due to the addition of strongly electronegative O atoms (The electronegativity difference with Co atoms is more obvious) to improve the matrix polarity. This makes the adsorbed Li2S have stronger Co–S bonds, which is highly consistent with the adsorption energy calculation. Besides, the charge transfer amount of Li2S to Co-O2N2 (0.772 e−) is greater than that to Co-N4 (0.493 e−) based on the Bader charge calculation, which confirms that the addition of more electronegative O atoms improves the electron adsorption ability of Co-O2N2. The calculation results mentioned above reveal the enhanced interaction between Co-O2N2 structure and Li2S, favorably accelerating the electron migration, that is, the precondition of catalytic conversion [44]. Moreover, the Gibbs free energy data of S reduction reactions on the NG, Co-N4-C, and Co/NOC were calculated theoretically (Fig. 6c and Fig. S19). The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) in the transformation of Li2S2 to Li2S shows the largest rise, suggesting the rate-determining procedure. The ΔG value at the rate-determining procedure for the Co/NOC (0.51 eV) is lower than that for the NG (0.87 eV) and Co-N4-C (0.69 eV), indicating that the thermodynamics of S reduction on the Co/NOC is more favorable. In order to further uncover the increased electrocatalytic capacity of Co-O2N2 moiety, the dissolution energy barrier of Li2S on NG, Co-N4, and Co-O2N2 was also calculated (Fig. 6d–f). Induced by the Co-N4 electrocatalyst, the barrier for Li2S dissolution (1.067 eV) is much lower than that on NG (1.214 eV), indicating that Co atoms in Co-N4 are the active centers to promote Li2S decomposition. More importantly, the solid-liquid phase conversion of Li2S is further accelerated through the reduced dissolution barrier for Co-O2N2 (0.784 eV) with double oxygen heteroatoms being introduced into the Co coordination environments. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations display that the unique Co-O2N2 structure in Li-S batteries enhances the adsorbability and bidirectional redox conversion kinetics of LiPSs, which implies the significance of introducing befitting heteroatoms for regulation into the chemical coordination environments of Co single-atoms for the electrocatalyst design. Encouraged by the excellent electrocatalytic activity and enhanced chemical adsorption capacity of the Co-O2N2-modified diaphragm, we performed an ex-situ XPS characterization (Fig. S20a–e) to investigate its interactions with LiPSs. It is well known that electrons can be transferred from Sn2− of LiPSs to the empty orbital of the oxidized Co according to the Lewis acid-base theory [27,45]. Hence, the XPS peaks of atomic Co move significantly toward the lower binding energy during discharging progress (Fig. S20a). During the subsequent charging process, the XPS peaks reversibly shift to the left, declaring the chemical stability of Co single atoms in the redox process of Li-S batteries. In the S 2p spectra, the peak structures at 170.1 and 169.0 eV are associated with polythionate and thiosulfate, respectively (Fig. S20b). At 1.7 and 2.3 V, the formation of the S–Co bonds can be seen in the fitted S 2p spectra. Furthermore, the double peaks attributed to Li2S/Li2S2 at 163.3 and 162.1 eV are significantly enhanced at full discharge to 1.7 V, which agrees with the experimental results reported by Du et al. [46]. At a later charging step, the peak intensities of Li2S/Li2S2 become weaker with reversible oxidation of LiPSs, which is also easily seen in the Li 1s spectra (Fig. S20e). In view of the strong chemical bond between Co and polysulfide negative ions, the Li-ions of lithium polysulfides will spontaneously interact with the N atoms of Co-O2N2 and pyridinic N. The XPS peaks of the N–Co bond and pyridinic N increased from 398.3 and 397.6 to 398.9 eV during the discharge process, respectively (Fig. S20c). Meanwhile, the XPS peak of the O–Co bond increases from 530.6 to 531.5 eV due to the transfer of electrons from the oxygen atoms to Li ions (Fig. S20d). Importantly, the active centers of Co/NOC returned to the primordial state after charging, which is reflected by the right shift of the N 1s and O 1s XPS spectra, demonstrating a long-period validity of the electrocatalysts during the operation of Li-S batteries. For the Li2S6 solution in the presence of Co/NOC, the Raman peaks of Li2S6 are significantly weakened, which also verifies the strong adsorption of the Co-O2N2 moiety on polysulfides, thus suppressing the shuttle behavior of polysulfides (Fig. S20f). Other factors including large S loading, low temperature environment as well as barren electrolyte also need to be considered in the real application of Li-S batteries. In this research, we characterized the cyclic performance of LSBs-γ with different S loadings at 0.2 C (Fig. 7 a). The incipient reversible C s of LSBs-γ at various S areal loadings of 5.6, 8.8, and 12.0 mg cm−2 is 1160.7, 1120.0, and 1030.1 mAh g−1, respectively. After 100 cycles, the reversible C s is 900.5, 836.6, and 710.1 mAh g−1, and the C s retentions are 77.58%, 74.70%, and 68.94%, respectively. Therefore, LSBs-γ can provide a high areal C s of 12.36 mAh cm−2 and retain a desirable areal C s of 8.52 mAh cm−2 after 100 cycles, far exceeding the excellent lithium cell (∼4.0 mAh cm−2) [47] and surpassing many Li-S batteries employing other modified diaphragms (Table S3). At the same time, the LSBs-γ was further tested under the harsh low-temperature operating conditions. Fig. 7(b) shows the discharge and charge curves at 0.2 C within a broad temperature range of −20 to 28 °C. LSBs-γ has the typical discharge and charge curves of S redox within −10 to 28 °C, indicating outstanding low-temperature tolerance. When the temperature drops from 28 to −10 °C, the C s declines slightly from 1440.1 to 874.2 mAh g−1. Nevertheless, further decreasing the temperature to −20 °C leads to a sharp drop in the C s of LSBs-γ (271.7 mAh g−1) and a significant increase in overpotential, which can be resolved through innovating the electrolytes. Fig. 7(c) presents the stability of LSBs-γ under temperature changes. We find that LSBs-γ operates stably at every temperature, once again demonstrating the distinguished temperature resistance of Li-S batteries using Co/NOC modified separators. The increased discharge C s from −20 °C to room temperature (28 °C) can be ascribed to the enhanced interaction between the Co/NOC@PP separator and polysulfides, reduced electrolyte viscosity, and improved reaction kinetics. Besides, the long-period performance of LSBs-γ at low temperatures was tested (Fig. 7d). At −10 °C, the C s of LSBs-γ is 688.7 mAh g−1 in the first cycle and can still reach 564.5 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 1 C. These results manifest the effectiveness of the Co/NOC@PP separator in suppressing the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides and imparting good low-temperature long cycle performance to Li-S batteries. Low electrolyte dosage is the key condition for realizing low-cost and high-energy-density Li-S batteries. Here, we assembled Li-S batteries containing Co/NOC@PP separator using the cathode with a high S loading of 5.6 mg cm−2 and performed multi-cycle measurements in the barren electrolyte (electrolyte volume/S mass (E/S = 5.1 µL mg−1)). As depicted in Fig. S21, the areal C s of Li-S batteries equipped with Co/NOC@PP separator reaches 4.1 mAh cm−2 after 60 cycles at 0.2 C. The exceptional performance of the Co/NOC@PP separator is attributed to the special structure of Co/NOC, including GN-like carbon nanosheets with high S BET and suitable hierarchical porous structure, as well as well-dispersed monoatomic Co with O2N2 coordination. These prominent physical/chemical properties verify that Co/NOC@PP separator possesses good application prospects in Li-S batteries. 3 Conclusions In summary, monatomic Co with novel Co-O2N2 coordination configuration anchored in heteroatom (N, O)-doped carbon matrix (Co/NOC) is successfully prepared and used as a multifunctional separator modification material. Homogeneous integration of monodisperse Co-O2N2 and carbon matrix with increased carbon layer spacing is conducive to providing fast charge/mass transfer channels and exposing more SACs active sites. The results of experiments and first-principle calculations verify that Co-O2N2 moiety is a multifunctional active center, which not only effectively enhances the chemisorption of LiPSs, but also significantly catalyzes the bidirectional LiPSs conversion, thereby inhibiting the shuttle effect. What is even more impressive, the structure-property relationship between the special Co-O2N2 coordination structure and improved adsorption capacity and catalytic activity is accurately revealed. Therefore, the Li-S batteries with Co/NOC modified diaphragms at room temperature show a large initial C s of 1581.7 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, extraordinary rate performance (906.6 mAh g−1 at 3 C), excellent cycling performance of 771.1 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 2 C, and a high areal C s of 12.36 mAh cm−2 at high S loading. Furthermore, the superior areal C s of 5.98 mAh cm−2 can still be achieved under a lean electrolyte volume of E/S = 5.1 µL mg−1 and high S loading of 5.6 mg cm−2. What is more, the Li-S batteries can operate stably for a long time at 1 C at −10 °C. This work reveals the specific effects of the modulation of the local coordination environment of SACs on the adsorption and catalytic activity of polysulfide, and has important reference significance for the development of highly active SACs for high-value Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries suffer from the shuttle effect of soluble lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and slow redox kinetics, significantly limiting their practical application. Although single-atom catalysts (SACs) offer a promising strategy to address these challenges, designing materials with optimal adsorption force and high catalytic activity remains a grand challenge. Here, we present a cobalt (Co)-based SAC with unique Co-O2N2 coordination structures for Li-S batteries. Both experimental and theoretical studies demonstrate that O, N-coordinated Co single atoms anchored on a porous carbon framework (Co/NOC) effectively capture LiPSs and dramatically catalyze bidirectional polysulfide conversion. The expanded carbon layer spacing facilitates lithium ions diffusion and maximizes the exposure of active sites. As a result, Li-S batteries incorporating Co/NOC as separators exhibit outstanding rate performance (906.6 mAh g−1 at 3 C) and exceptional cycling stability, even at −10 °C. Furthermore, with a high sulfur loading of 12.0 mg cm−2, the areal specific capacity reaches up to 12.36 mAh cm−2. This work provides some useful insights for the design of high-performance SACs for Li-S batteries.
